title: Multiple chat elements for one browsed URL
body:
### User Story

As a user I only want to see the URLs I opened on the home screen once, so that my chat list is less cluttered. 

### Description

*Type*: Feature

*Summary*: 

Each time I open the same URL from a chat or from the browser, it is added to the home screen again as a new chat element, cluttering the screen. 

These should be de-duplicated:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15470435/42231361-a734e580-7eeb-11e8-9ce4-e68a7002708f.png)


#### Expected behavior

When I open the same URL twice, it only appears in my chat list once. The second time I open it, it is at the top of the list again.

This applies only to exact duplicate URLs. 

This should be effective when I:
- Open the same URL twice from a chat
- Navigate to the same URL twice in the browser

#### Actual behavior
The same URL is added to the chats list as a new chat element each time it was opened


### Reproduction
- Open Status
- Navigate to a chat (one to one, group or public)
- Send a URL
- Open the URL (Tap on it and 'Open in browser')
- Press back button to return to the chats list
- Open the chat again
- Tap and open the URL again
- Press back button to return to the chats list


### Additional Information
* Status version: 0.9.10-776-g9cae0a5d+ (nightly build 277 from March 16)
* Operating System:
Real device LG V20, Android 7.0
Real device iPhone 8+, iOS 11.1.1
@yevh-berdnyk  Could you ask an opinion somebody from design team before you are posting UX related issues? What you mentioned here is made by design

@denis-sharypin sorry, didn't know it's only about design.
So do you mean it's not an issue and should be left as it is?
@yevh-berdnyk  yep!
It was discussed and agreed being an issue

Balance: 0 ETH
Tokens: SNT: 1000.00
Contract address: [0xd4cad6c4d66650d1cc5346bdb017e7e80b7a5b5a](https://etherscan.io/address/0xd4cad6c4d66650d1cc5346bdb017e7e80b7a5b5a)
Network: Mainnet
Paid to: kennytilton
Visit [https://openbounty.status.im](https://openbounty.status.im) to learn more.
Which of N duplicates should be shown, the most recent or the oldest?
@kennytilton Does that make a concrete difference? I would go with last one.
Oh I think I got your point. We should definitely keep the most recent one (higher in the list)

Thanks, I should have made clearer the consequence I saw, viz., the list is sorted to show most recent first, so taking the most recent maps to that ordering better, otherwise an entry moves to the bottom.
This seems to have been fixed by commit a644075310c on 2018-07-06.

hey guys, this issue hasn't been fixed, let me suggest one solution, we generate new id for every link from chat or for every new open url , https://github.com/status-im/status-react/blob/develop/src/status_im/ui/screens/browser/events.cljs#L47. i think we could use the host as a browser id, in that case, we will have only one item for every host on the home screen

Ok, my current obviously unreliable impression (after a hard stare at the new model.browser code and some testing to confirm) is that the exact "Reproduction" story above -- dupes after *consecutive* visits to the same URL  -- is fixed. But the overall report is about *any* dupes consecutive or not, and that indeed is what I have been working on, and that is not fixed.

My approach was to leave history untouched and de-dupe in the :home-items subscription, thinking the problem is screen clutter so do the de-duping when preparing the screen elements. This has the advantage of otherwise preserving history. The fix is also straightforward: just toss (older) extras where the URL is the same. I have that code ready to go after I adjust it for the new browser structure.

But then we would have logic in browser.model de-duping consecutive visits unnecessarily, unless it serves some other purpose of which I am unaware.
OK, turned out to be a one-word change to my fix, `:url` -> `browser/get-current-url`. PR later after I study up on the mechanics.
Yes, @flexsurfer , thanks and I *did* run that red light, except I was already done with my coding and I thought my approach was the least intrusive. But I should have hit the brakes. :)

Ok, one thing, @flexsurfer: the suggested approach of using the host as the browser-id is dead simple but a deep change that would, if I do it well, require me to track down all uses of the browser list and make sure I am not breaking anything. Or can someone such as yourself just direct me to do it that way? My thinking was, the stated problem is clutter, so de-clutter the screen. ie, Without altering the browser data being recorded or anything more invasive. Furthermore, it may develop that other kinds of de-cluttering are someday requested. Then we just expand the de-duping mechanism. If instead we figure out a way to de-dupe internally, future filtering will likely still need a last-second massaging of the data presented on the screen. Anyway...

Can we safely settle on using the host as the browser-id, or should I track down all its usage?
yes @kennytilton it's safe and we can just use `host` as `browser-id`,  we already use dapp name as `browser-id`, so it'll work the same but uses `host` instead `name` , thanks

I looked around and did not see any existing utility for extracting the host from a URL, but cemerick has a small clj/cljs lib that is testing well: https://github.com/cemerick/url. I propose we go with that instead of some ad hoc regex. A second question is whether to attempt to switch existing history to the new `browser-id` as it is pulled from storage on login. The alternative is to endure a more or less brief period of duplication until historical entries get cleared. Worth it?
GitHub
cemerick/url
url - Makes working with URLs in Clojure and ClojureScript easy

@kennytilton i'm not sure about a library, we're trying to do not add external libraries, better to just get necessary function, and copy it to our utilities, second question, don't worry about history and old browsers it's not worth it. Thanks

@jeluard @flexsurfer FYI I am proceeding (a) with cemerick's url lib and (b) exploring converting legacy (stored) browsers to the new browser-id. Not sure if I need to re-write storage or not, but will pop back here as I learn more.
@kennytilton have you seen my comment above?
@flexsurfer Yes, got it. Thx. Will do: pull the URL parser into our code, don't sweat history.

Ok, @flexsurfer and @jeluard : I thought I would get pre-approval for my current plan, which is a simple function `url-domain` wrapping `(.getDomain (goog.Uri url))` and using that to derive `:browser-id` (instead of the current random key). Since `goog.Uri` will thow an error on an input such as "42", I propose wrapping the above in a try-catch and simply returning nil on any invalid input, but then we need to alter the `:open-browser-in-url` event handler not to record/execute the open event. But then do we silently not navigate or alert the user to an internal failure? The alternative is to let the original exception go uncaught, or to throw a more scrutable error saying sth. like "url-domain input url '42' is not a valid Uri".  Then we still have the question of the user experience. Mind you, it may be that the new code can simply assume valid URLs will be found in the event url argument, in which case everything gets a lot simpler. Please advise. ps. I am guessing that the dependency on goog.Uri is OK since that is a guaranteed CLJS presence.

Looks good to me! The alternative is even better.
@flexsurfer WDYT ?

> Le 20 juil. 2018  16:05, Kenneth Tilton <notifications@github.com> a crit :
> 
> Ok, @flexsurfer and @jeluard : I thought I would get pre-approval for my current plan, which is a simple function url-domain wrapping (.getDomain (goog.Uri url)) and using that to derive :browser-id (instead of the current random key). Since goog.Uri will thow an error on an input such as "42", I propose wrapping the above in a try-catch and simply returning nil on any invalid input, but then we need to alter the :open-browser-in-url event handler not to record/execute the open event. But then do we silently not navigate or alert the user to an internal failure? The alternative is to let the original exception go uncaught, or to throw a more scrutable error saying sth. like "url-domain input url '42' is not a valid Uri". Then we still have the question of the user experience. Mind you, it may be that the new code can simply assume valid URLs will be found in the event url argument, in which case everything gets a lot simpler. Please advise.
>

Another even more minimalist solution that just came to me is, should goog.Uri not come up with a domain-name, hey, just fall back on the random key and whatever happens downstream, on the navigation I mean, is what would happen anyway, so we address duplication without introducing any new issue that would arise anyway if somehow bad urls started sneaking through.

@kennytilton sorry for the slow response on bounty payout, could you drop your wallet address here so I can send you the bounty amount Out of Band while we wait on a dashboard fix in Status Open Bounty. 

If you don't feel comfortable putting it here in the comment could you email a ERC20 compatible wallets address to me? chris.hutchinson@status.im

OK, I have a Coinbase wallet but that is not ERC20 yet. I have a Status
wallet but when I try to send a "receive" transaction it wants me to select
a contact and I can see no way to add contacts.

What do you recommend? MyEtherWallet?

Thx, Ken
